climbs.name: You, Me, and Everyone We Know

content.description:
Clip the first glue-in bolt pointing down on a roof, then pull over it via a right hand finger crack, revealing fifteen meters of .10- climbing to a good rest below an attractive, just off vertical blank slab. There are potentially several ways through this obstacle, but if you climb directly through the slab instead of sneaking left or right of this offset, give yourself a cookie. 

  I climbed this recently about a year after the FA. I think in retrospect that this might be .10+. I'm interested in other opinions of the grade. My sense is that it's sort of soft at .11-, but it's not inaccurate to label it thus.
content.location: Just right of Blue Grouse. Easily discerned by the glue-in first bolt pointing almost straight down in a two foot wide roof

content.description: Sustained 5.7 moves for about 2/3 of the route where is eases.  Pro can be a puzzle.
content.location: 15' left of Bulge Boogy.  Start in a low point in the trail.  Setting up a simple belay anchor recommended.

content.description: This climb features unique climb for the cliff, and should be on your list for sure! Solve the puzzling crux, and save some energy for the finish!
content.location: Just right of a large roof towering over the trail.

content.description: The route can be climbed a number of ways giving various difficulties. The first crux is at the 6' plate going straight up is a balancing act and crimpy, (difficult for shorter folks) the top has various lines and ranges from low to high 10. As always if you are in the moss you are off route. The first ascencionist got a speeding ticket driving home(and no it was not me this time).
content.location: Shares the same shade tree as Eaglet

content.description: Mixed Route.  Start as Trad Dad, check your courage and eventually move left to bolts and back to the Trad Dad anchors.
content.protection: It's possible to place gear or just use the bolts (2).  PG13 if no gear used.

content.description: Just past the anchors to Eaglet comes a 8'x10' horizontal roof. There is one bolt in the roof and one on the lip.    Its mid 12 at the moment, lets get some more folks on it and get a better consensus. Thxs
content.location: Coming from the cars its in the first clearing after gaining the cliff band walking south, can't miss the roof!

content.description: This is the route leading up to the big roof. Please start close to the base of the Kestrel route and tiptoe across the blocks at the bottom leaving the vegetation in tact. The route rolls up an easy slab to a small roof above the 4th bolt and the crux, after a bit more you arrive under the massive roof and a set of anchors.
content.protection: 9 bolts, rap anchor under the roof with Mussey hooks.
content.location: After leaving the dense woods it is the first big roof in the clearing.

content.description: A bit difficult above the first bolt, crux is just above the fourth bolt where the feet get bad, and then a bit of a burn getting to the anchors. This is the bird I named my daughter after, one of my favorites while climbing, joyfully darting around the cliffs.
content.location: Just to the right of Osprey

content.description: Fun, aesthetic movement through several crux bulges. Don't get burned by leaving your medium nuts and cams at the base.
content.protection: 9 bolts? two large nuts or medium cams.

content.description: Well bolted beginner route with a non traditional start move. Side pulls, under clings, lay backs.   A little background: on my forays up to Cooper Spur I would call out to what I thought was an owl hooting at me; four hoots and I would respond with four, this would go on until I couldn't hear anymore 1/2mi or more away. Turns out it was a Blue Grouse and it is their mating call; no wonder they kept up so long!
content.location: On the same column as Felsschlüpfer just to climbers right.

content.description: This is the 3rd wall, and hosts some great new routes, including a burly roof line.
